content.title: Myopathy Overview
content.summary: Disorders of skeletal muscle causing weakness, typically with proximal predominance, elevated creatine kinase, and myopathic findings on EMG and muscle biopsy
key_points: Primary muscle disorder vs secondary to nerve disease (neuropathy)
Proximal weakness pattern: difficulty rising from chair, climbing stairs, lifting arms
Elevated CK (creatine kinase) reflects muscle damage
EMG shows myopathic pattern (small, brief, polyphasic motor units)
Muscle biopsy often needed for definitive diagnosis
Inflammatory myopathies are treatable; dystrophies have limited treatment

statement.text: Myopathy is a general term for diseases of skeletal muscle characterized by weakness without sensory loss, typically affecting proximal muscles more than distal. Patients present with difficulty climbing stairs, rising from chairs, and reaching overhead. Laboratory evaluation shows elevated creatine kinase, EMG demonstrates myopathic motor units, and muscle biopsy provides definitive diagnosis. Myopathies are classified as inflammatory (treatable), genetic/dystrophic, toxic/metabolic, or endocrine.
statement.formal: Myopathy = Proximal weakness + Elevated CK + Myopathic EMG + No sensory loss | Classification = Inflammatory | Genetic | Toxic | Endocrine

explanation.intuition: In myopathy, the muscle fibers themselves are damaged or dysfunctional, while the nerves supplying them remain intact. This explains why patients have weakness but no numbness (sensory fibers are fine) and why the largest muscles (proximal, used for big movements) are typically affected first. When muscle cells break down, they release their contents (CK) into the blood, making CK a useful marker.
explanation.key_insight: The proximal > distal weakness pattern is key for distinguishing myopathy from neuropathy (which typically shows distal > proximal). However, some myopathies (like myotonic dystrophy, inclusion body myositis) have distal involvement, so clinical context matters. The combination of weakness pattern, CK level, EMG findings, and muscle biopsy allows accurate classification.
explanation.technical_details: EMG in myopathy shows early recruitment of small, brief, polyphasic motor unit potentials because individual muscle fibers are damaged (reducing motor unit amplitude) but the number of motor units is preserved (early recruitment). Muscle biopsy can distinguish inflammatory (lymphocyte infiltration), dystrophic (fiber size variation, fibrosis), metabolic (storage material), and mitochondrial (ragged red fibers) myopathies.

definitions_glossary.myopathy: Any disease affecting skeletal muscle, causing weakness and often elevated muscle enzymes
definitions_glossary.proximal_weakness: Weakness affecting muscles close to body center (shoulders, hips, thighs)
definitions_glossary.creatine_kinase: Muscle enzyme released into blood when muscle cells are damaged; marker of myopathy
definitions_glossary.inflammatory_myopathy: Myopathy caused by autoimmune muscle inflammation (dermatomyositis, polymyositis, IBM)
definitions_glossary.muscular_dystrophy: Inherited progressive myopathy caused by mutations in structural muscle proteins
definitions_glossary.myotonia: Delayed relaxation after muscle contraction; seen in myotonic dystrophy, channelopathies
definitions_glossary.dermatomyositis: Inflammatory myopathy with characteristic skin findings (heliotrope rash, Gottron papules)
definitions_glossary.polymyositis: Inflammatory myopathy without skin findings; diagnosis of exclusion
definitions_glossary.inclusion_body_myositis: Inflammatory myopathy in elderly with characteristic distal and asymmetric weakness
definitions_glossary.duchenne_muscular_dystrophy: X-linked dystrophinopathy with severe progressive weakness, cardiomyopathy
definitions_glossary.statin_myopathy: Muscle toxicity from statin medications; ranges from myalgia to rhabdomyolysis
definitions_glossary.rhabdomyolysis: Severe muscle breakdown with markedly elevated CK (>10x normal), risk of renal failure
definitions_glossary.myopathic_emg: EMG pattern with small, brief, polyphasic motor units and early recruitment

pathophysiology.mechanism: Myopathies result from damage to muscle fibers through various mechanisms: (1) inflammatory - autoimmune T-cell or antibody-mediated attack; (2) genetic - structural protein defects (dystrophin, sarcoglycans) causing membrane instability; (3) metabolic - enzyme deficiencies affecting energy production (glycogenoses, lipid storage); (4) toxic - direct muscle toxicity from drugs or toxins.
muscle_fiber_injury: Inflammatory: T-cell cytotoxicity (polymyositis, IBM), complement-mediated microangiopathy (dermatomyositis)
Dystrophic: Muscle membrane instability from structural protein defects
Metabolic: Impaired ATP production affecting muscle contraction
Toxic: Direct mitochondrial damage or impaired protein synthesis
pathophysiology.ck_elevation_mechanism: CK is concentrated in muscle cytoplasm. When muscle cell membranes are disrupted, CK leaks into bloodstream. CK levels correlate roughly with degree and acuity of muscle damage but not with functional severity.

weakness_pattern.proximal: Difficulty climbing stairs, rising from chair, lifting arms (most myopathies)
weakness_pattern.distal: Finger/wrist weakness, foot drop (myotonic dystrophy, IBM)

associated_findings.myalgia: Muscle pain; common in inflammatory and toxic myopathies

red_flags.skin_changes: Heliotrope rash, Gottron papules = dermatomyositis (cancer association)

laboratory_evaluation.other_labs: Aldolase, LDH, AST (from muscle), myositis-specific antibodies (anti-Jo-1, anti-Mi-2, anti-MDA5)

electrodiagnostics.emg_findings: Small, brief, polyphasic motor unit potentials; early recruitment; fibrillations/PSW indicate active denervation

muscle_biopsy.inflammatory: Perivascular inflammation (DM), endomysial inflammation (PM/IBM), rimmed vacuoles (IBM)
muscle_biopsy.dystrophic: Fiber size variation, internal nuclei, fibrosis, fat replacement; immunostaining for specific proteins
muscle_biopsy.metabolic: Glycogen or lipid storage; ragged red fibers (mitochondrial)

inflammatory_myopathies.ibm: No proven effective treatment; IVIG may have modest benefit

muscular_dystrophies.duchenne: Corticosteroids slow progression; eteplirsen, deflazacort (FDA approved)
muscular_dystrophies.supportive: Physical therapy, orthopedic management, cardiac monitoring, respiratory support

toxic_myopathies.statin: Discontinue statin; symptoms usually improve in weeks to months

definition.@value: Diseases of skeletal muscle characterized by weakness, typically proximal, with elevated creatine kinase and myopathic EMG findings

skos.scopeNote: Overview of myopathies including inflammatory, genetic, toxic, and endocrine etiologies; individual subtypes have dedicated AKUs
skos.example: A 50-year-old woman with progressive difficulty climbing stairs and rising from chairs over 6 months, CK 2500 U/L, heliotrope rash around eyes; diagnosed with dermatomyositis, treated with prednisone

learning_objectives: Differentiate myopathy from neuropathy based on clinical features and EMG
Classify myopathies into inflammatory, genetic, toxic, and endocrine categories
Interpret CK levels in the context of myopathy diagnosis
Select appropriate diagnostic workup including EMG and muscle biopsy
Recognize treatable inflammatory myopathies requiring immunosuppression
clinical_pearls: Proximal weakness (trouble with stairs, rising, reaching) = myopathy; distal weakness = neuropathy (usually)
CK can be 10-100x elevated in active myopathy; very high CK (>10,000) = rhabdomyolysis
Dermatomyositis has malignancy association - cancer screening recommended
IBM: elderly male, distal/asymmetric, treatment-resistant - don't mistake for polymyositis
Statin myopathy: stop statin, CK normalizes in weeks; rechallenge with different statin possible
Normal CK doesn't exclude myopathy - some chronic/burned-out myopathies have normal CK
common_misconceptions: All myopathies have elevated CK (false - burned-out or some metabolic myopathies may have normal CK)
Polymyositis is common (false - IBM is more common; PM may be overdiagnosed)
Myopathy always causes proximal weakness (false - IBM, myotonic dystrophy have distal involvement)
Statins cause only mild muscle symptoms (false - can cause rhabdomyolysis in rare cases)

skos:related.skos:note: Key differential; neuropathy has sensory involvement and distal predominance
Differential for fluctuating weakness; NMJ disorder, not myopathy
